Article.ArticleTitle: Changes in biophysical characteristics of PFN1 due to mutation causing amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

AbstractText: Single amino acid mutations in profilin 1 (PFN1) have been found to cause amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Recently, we developed a mouse model for ALS using a PFN1 mutation (glycine 118 to valine, G118V), and we are now interested in understanding how PFN1 becomes toxically lethal with only one amino acid substitution. Therefore, we studied mutation-related changes in the PFN1 protein and hypothesized that such changes significantly disturb its structure. Initially, we expressed and studied the purified PFN1<sup>WT</sup> and PFN1<sup>G118V</sup> proteins from bacterial culture. We found that the PFN1<sup>G118V</sup> protein has a different mean residue ellipticity, as measured by far-UV circular dichroism, accompanied by a spectral shift. The intrinsic fluorescence of PFN1<sup>G118V</sup> showed a small fluctuation in maximum fluorescence absorption and intensity. Moreover, we examined the time course of PFN1 aggregation using SDS-PAGE, western blotting, and MALDI-TOF/TOF and found that compared with PFN1<sup>WT</sup>, PFN1<sup>G118V</sup> had an increased tendency to form aggregates. Dynamic light scattering data confirmed this, showing a larger size distribution for PFN1<sup>G118V</sup>. Our data explain why PFN1<sup>G118V</sup> tends to aggregate, a phenotype that may be the basis for its neurotoxicity.
